qas.question: What does the acronym LER refer to?
What is the maximum LER possible?
In how many ways can one define luminous efficacy of a light source?
What is the definition of radiant luminous efficacy?

answers.text: the ratio of the visible light flux emitted (the luminous flux) to the total power radiated over all wavelengths

qas.question: What does the acronym LES refer to?
What may be defined in three ways?
What does the acronym LER not stand for?
What does the acronym LES not stand for?
What is not the ratio of the visible light flux emitted to the total power input to the source?
What is the minimum LER possible?

context: <b5_0>Luminous efficacy<b5_0/> of a light source may be defined in <a2_0>two ways<a2_0/>. The <a0_0><b6_0>radiant luminous efficacy<b6_0/><a0_0/> (LER) is <a3_0>the ratio of the visible light flux emitted (the luminous flux) to the total power radiated over all wavelengths<a3_0/>. The <a4_0><b7_0><b8_0>source luminous efficacy<b7_0/><a4_0/> (LES)<b8_0/> is the ratio of the visible light flux emitted (the luminous flux) to the total power input to the source, such as a lamp. Visible light is measured in lumens, a unit which is defined in part by the differing sensitivity of the human eye to different wavelengths of light. Not all wavelengths of visible electromagnetic energy are equally effective at stimulating the human eye; the luminous efficacy of radiant energy (LER) is a measure of how well the distribution of energy matches the perception of the eye. The units of luminous efficacy are "lumens per watt" (lpw). The maximum LER possible is <a1_0><b9_0>683 lm/W<b9_0/><a1_0/> for monochromatic green light at 555 nanometers wavelength, the peak sensitivity of the human eye.
